author: {'steamid': '76561198011492308', 'num_games_owned': 451, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 842, 'last_played': 1706524102}
review:
I really like it, but it feels more frustrating than difficult/fun. But I hit #1 on the leaderboards, so, that has to count for something.

It's wonderful to look at and plays pretty well, although I have some reservations about the control scheme (at least, playing on mouse.) Watching the enemy ships come apart is basically what kept me playing.

My first issue is a feeling of "That's it?" Admittedly, Furious Angels does advertise itself as a score attack shooter with different waves every day, so, I can't fault it for that, but I was just left with this feeling of wanting more from it.

My real issue is some of the enemies and how much feedback the game would give me. It feels like some enemies would kill me immediately, such as Bombers, or their missiles would be affected by how I was turning or manoeuvring. And sometimes I'd just get vaporized. Miners were similar, but at least's clear how they worked. What unites them both is how un-fun they became if a daily wave focused heavily on them. I've watched some videos on Youtube and it feels like I was dealing with a lot more mines and missiles.

I also find the system where if you travel too far from the carrier, it'd get ambushed and almost immediately destroyed by an enemy carrier to be more frustrating than anything else. The game doesn't tell you how far you can wander from your carrier, and I had a few runs where I'd be ejected from my tank upgrade at such a velocity that I'd fall outside the zone and see my carrier get blown up in seconds. Not fun.

The upgrade system isn't communicated ideally either. The core idea is pretty obvious. You get kills, you get a new type of weapon, and so on. Homing missiles, multi-shot, a laser beam. But I had to dig around to find out what the "Mark" system did (a global damage upgrade up to a maximum of five) and I'm not actually sure if that's communicated in the game anywhere. I also generally don't like upgrade systems that make optimal play sacrificing them early (you should immediately sacrifice your Mark 1 and Mark 2 tanks) and generally don't reward keeping them as long as possible.

All that said, for under $10 you can't go wrong if you want to fly around and blow stuff up. But it does feel a lot like a prototype of a game that might've had more upgrades, more enemies, more everything.

review:
The good: not very expensive, good graphics, runs even on a toaster, good controls, and the gameplay is good.
The bad: there's very little gameplay to actually experience.
It's easy to see everything in the game in 15-30 minutes, everything after that is grinding for a higher spot on the leaderboard: the game is so simple there's not even much in the way of improving your skills and coming up with better tactics, it's just a matter of doing run after run after run for hours and hours while 85% of players never played for more than 1 hour in a day.

Ah there's also an achievement for getting 1st spot on the leaderboard at the end of the day, let's look at recent leaderboards to see how feasible it is: in the first spot we always have the same guy with 50000+ points, second and third spot usually have around 5000 points.
This brilliant idea somehow resulted in a massive influx of cheaters, who could have seen that coming? It's not like cheaters love to ruin other players' fun, after all...
developer_response: Yes, the "Furious" achievement can be silly but I can assure you there is no influx of cheaters (even tho there has been a few in the past). Those guys taking the top spot are actually just using the combo system (and a few other tactics) to the full extent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198300270231', 'num_games_owned': 5388, 'num_reviews': 894, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1642673368}
review:
스팀 지천에 깔린 '슈팅'과 '스코어 어택' 게임을 접목시킨 [b]《격분한 천사들》[/b]이다. 게임은 정말 간단하다. 한정된 공간 내에서, 이동하며, 적기를 격추시키면 끝. 적기의 종류 또한 크게 5가지[i](봄버, 스콜피온, 마인, 임포스터, 캐리어)[/i]로 상당히 단순한 편. 보스전 그런 개념도 없다. 갈수록 더 많이 스폰되는 적들을 오로지 갈아버리면 그만. 개인적으로는 진입하기도 쉽고, 숙련되기도 쉬운 [b]Easy to Learn, Easy to Master[/b] 게임이라고 생각한다. 근데 말이야··· 그게 다 무슨 소용일까. 나의 노력 여부와는 상관 없는 도전과제가 남아 있는 것을·····.

+ 깔끔한 그래픽으로 적들에 대한 시인성이 높은 편
+ 나름 괜찮은 타격감(특히 슬로 모션일 때 느낌 좋음)
+ 군더더기 없이 잘 빠진 조작감
+ 각 적기마다 다른 공격 형태를 보유하고 있음
+ 업그레이드 시스템 또한 존재함

- 지.독.하.기.그.지.없.는.랭.킹.1.등.의.압.도.적.존.재.감
- 개같이 의미 없는 '명중 50% 이상으로 첫 업그레이드 100회' 도전과제 
- 따라서, 도전과제 올클리어가 순전히 상대방에게 달렸다

후··· 시​​​발, 아무리 내가 10만점, 20만점 가까이 찍으면 뭐하냐고. 도전과제 올클리어는 내 실력 여부와는 아무런 상관이 없다. 믿어라, 결국 [i]'고인물 또는 핵쟁이들'[/i]이 게임을 하느냐 마느냐로 운명이 갈린다. 솔직히 나는 4-5 캐리어까지 무난하게 가면 이 게임을 마스터했다라고 본다. 3 캐리어 등장할 때 '콤보 150 이상' 유지가 가능하다? 축하한다, 그럼 당신은 12만점 이상은 우습게 찍을 수 있는 센스를 겸비하게 된 것이다. 1등? 어우 말할 것도 없이 쌉가능이지. 대게 5만점 이상이면 5위 안으로 거의 확정이나 다름 없으니 말이야.

자, 문제는 36시간마다 꼭 한번씩 들러서 최소 30만점, 많게는 몇백만 점을 띄우고 가는 고인물이나, 플레이 타임 5분도 안 되서 200만점 이상 띄우는 핵쟁이 새​​​​끼들이 있다는 것. 이놈들은 장판파의 장비가 따로 없다. Furious 도전과제로 가는 다리를 떡 하니 막고서, 후발주자에게 길을 내어주지 않는 것이다. 그들에게 있어서는 게임에 대한 열정의 표출이겠으나, 사실상 당하는 입장에서는 꼬장부리는 걸로 밖에 안 느껴진다. 레알, 이 게임 도전과제 올클리어 노릴 거면 기도 메타 장착해라. 그저 [i]'제발, 이번 36시간 동안은 고인물이나 핵쟁이가 플레이하지 않길.'[/i] 비는 수밖에 없다. 그리고 그 기도가 통했던 것일까. 결국 나는 25만점에 가까운 스코어로 1등을 차지할 수 있었다. 후, 장판파를 건넜기에 일단 엄지는 올리도록 하겠다. 게임성 또한 이 정도 가성비면 나쁘지 않은 거 같고.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994641567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1704602588}
review:
Great little twinstick that looks fantastic and plays really well.

Enough enemy variety to keep the combat interesting, but not so much as to overwhelm.  You have to prioritise targets and dodge or tank or ram enemies in an ever-evolving ship that keeps you on your toes, with each stage having different strengths and weaknesses and tricks to handling and damaging.

It's got the classic "stop shooting to repair" system, which I think fits really well.  You can play the game aggressively to max your combo, or you can play slowly and focus on trying to stay alive.  The twin health bars of your own ship and the mothership your are 'defending' really plays into the dynamic of the game making you think on your feet.

Each day the waves are randomized, however they are the same in the same order for each day.  This means that you can try repeatedly to learn today's pattern, but there's always a slightly new arrangement to come back to next time.  Each day has its own leaderboard, so you can chase the high score or see how you rank.

If I had one complaint it is that the game has a bit of hidden information that could easily be explained in something as simple as an enemy-identification logbook.  But as it stands, delving into the Steam Guides is your only option at present.  The music is decent; I like the tracks but there only seem to be two of them.

Overall, Furious Angels is a great game, and well worth it's price for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134219338', 'num_games_owned': 1038, 'num_reviews': 768, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1654122937}
review:
Played on Steam Deck.

All flash but no substance. It worked perfectly on Deck with the twin-stick controls, and I really just wish there was more to this game but you just fly around for a few minutes and only get three ship upgrades and then die and do it again. At minimum it is missing upgrade options or further upgrades, something interesting to make you feel like you are engaging with the game. Doing the same exact run, same waves, is very repetitive and gets boring fast. Any kind of campaign or multiplayer or roguelite elements would make this game much better. It is even more discouraging to see that the steam achievements may be trying to bait a sort of "replayability" by having achievements such as: "Get the first upgrade with over 50% accuracy 100 times" or "Kill 10,000 jets" or even "Finish the day in the first position" all of which seem like they are just trying to bait you into playing more are just doing more pointless runs instead of having the game be actually fun.

Even for a sale price this is less than an hour of enjoyment.

review:
[h1] Flyin' Fast and Furious [/h1]
Awesome arcade game, awesome dev (Morfeo) who listens to the community!
This game is straight forward, no splash screens, no popup logos, no b u l l s h i t, the first button press gets you right into the action flying with full control! 
Very steep learning curve, but there's fun during it all, beginning, getting better and "late"-game when you last longer. 
Very interesting game mechanics which give way for different strategies. Every 36 hours the leaderboard resets and so does the enemy waves mixing it all up requiring you to adapt and invent a new strategy for this particular day.
Achievement hunters be warned: There's an achievement to become first on the leaderboard for one day. At the moment there are crazy good players dominating the daily leaderboard and still improving themselves. Almost impossible if you get unlucky. 

Very good arcade gem! Go get it already, pilot!

review:
Furious Angels est un shmup multidirectionnel extrêmement bien réalisé.
Le gameplay est extrêmement simple : un stick pour contrôler l'avion et l'autre pour les tirs.
Sachant qu'il faut arrêter de tirer régulièrement pour recharger sa vie.

Au bout d'un certain nombre d'ennemis abattus on obtient des upgrades qui nous feront passer du petit avion rapide au char d'assaut très lent, puis on repasse en avion quand le char a encaissé trop de dégâts.

Chaque jour les leaderboards sont remis à zéro et les vagues d'ennemis sont modifiées, donc il faudra adapter sa stratégie pour survivre le plus longtemps possible. 
Les jeux de MorfeoDev sont basés sur gameplay et débarrassés de tout scénario ou aspects superflus pour se concentrer sur l'essentiel. Et ça marche!

Bravo au développeur pour l'optimisation du jeu, car il tourne à 60 fps un Mac mini de 2011 avec puce Intel HD 3000 (en 720p et post processing désactivé).
Je vous conseille d'aller voir l'autre jeu de MorfeoDev "Afterburn" qui est tout aussi bien optimisé et beaucoup plus aboutit au niveau du gameplay : du combat aérien frénétique en vue subjective dans le même univers graphique que Furious Angels.

review:
Furious Angels is a 2.5D twin stick shmup featuring low poly 3D rendered graphics.   Unlike a more traditional arcade shmup, you fight waves of enemies that come from all directions. 

Usually low poly graphics, like retro pixel "art", are hallmarks of lazy/low budget/talentless devs, but they don't look completely terrible here, and the game does support 4K graphics (although the settings are spartan).   The chief problem is they built this game engine but had no idea where to go with it, so it's ultimately just a high-score/leaderboard game.  There was potential here, if they added some scrolling instead of tired, dead, lazy survival shooter mechanics, and of course added some kind of level design or story/stages/progression etc.

This is not the most terrible indie game I've been forced to endure, but it falls far below its own potential.

review:
何となくやっていてタイムパイロットを思い出すゲーム。
慣性の付くアステロイドをマイルドにした様な動きなので、普通の全方位シューとも微妙に違い、ドッグファイトしてる感がある。
また、生き延びているとパワーアップパーツがやってきて合体し、それが装甲の役割も果たす。
時間が経つ程、強力なパーツが来るが、大きく遅くなるので一長一短ではある。
また、敵の戦艦は母船を攻撃し、母船がやられても負けなので、あまり母船から離れると知らない内に終わってしまうので注意。
敵の種類が少なく単調だし、ノーマル状態の攻撃のチマチマ感やゲームモードが1つしかない部分で、どうも印象はあまり良くないのだが、妙な中毒性があって、納得いかないやられ方をすると再プレイしてしまうところがある。
正直、100円とかバンドルに入ってたら試してもいい感じでオススメとは言い難いが、貶すほどつまらないとも思えず、一応、おすすめの方にしておく。

Fast and and furious action, this game delivers. You play a lone fighter off a carrier that apparently has nothing left... Not even guns to protect itself. But enemies gets tougher and tougher.  Minibases has tracking turrets that will wreck you. Minelayers throws out mines. And carrier... well, will fry your carrier. 

It's an adrenaline rush to survive more than a few minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198414140254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 24186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1090, 'last_played': 1710466122}
review:
FA is a minimalistic, short and sweet arcade dogfighting shooter that is so much more than what you may think. Somewhat easy to get into, decently hard to get a hold of, and generally a good pick for coffee breaks... Not always though!


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Furious Angels (FA in short) is all about... blowing stuff up. While trying not to die. All while babysitting the helpless mothership. And of course, get a good looking score. Oh, and there’s no campaign, no story, no upgrade grinding. Only explosions. And scores.

Your goal - face the endless hordes of enemies that want you and your mothership dead. Losing either is a Game Over. Stay alive as long as you can, get that big big combo, but your fate is sealed before it all begins. You’ll lose. As for how, it’s up to you to decide.

[h2]Controls[/h2]
Initially, the controls were awkward for me. It felt slow, and drifty. You can’t turn on a dime. FA is, you can say, more realistic in terms of handling.

Key presses on the keyboard translates to general (screen absolute) strafing direction, giving you the ability to make smoothly angled turns without actually having to use a controller. This has a side effect of causing movement in the unintended direction. The existence of inertia in a twin stick shooter might turn some people off. Luckily, some practice can easily get you comfortable with it.

Should you require more accurate directional controls, FA even allows you to use a controller for movement while your mouse does the aiming and pew-pew’s. Or you can just use the mouse alone if you want some self imposed challenge...

[h2]Enemies[/h2]
Enemies are separated into a total of 7 categories, which isn’t a lot, but there aren’t any two that are “more or less the same”.

Let’s see what we have: Jets, these come in swarms; Raptors are like copies of the player, faster, agile, and don’t hesitate in spitting a stream of shots in your direction;  Bombers waddle around, shooting homing missiles in 4; Scorpions fire 4 bullets with movement prediction; Miners lay homing mines with high damage (the most hated enemy ever); Impostors are a copy of your tank and like to flank you with a volley of fast traveling shots; finally, the Carriers spawn a lot of Raptors and beam your mothership with their huge ion cannon. That’s all you get.

The fact is that, even with such a limited cast of enemies, they can already wreck havoc on our poor little jet and helpless mothership.

The enemies are one of the shining points of FA, easily my favorite.

[h2]Scoring system[/h2]
The scoring system in FA is easy to understand, with an incredibly high skill ceiling. At the end of the day, it’s all about controlling the flow.

Enemies come in waves that increase in both size and pace. Killing enemies adds to a combo that goes on forever, until you break it. 

Meanwhile, your jet also upgrades as you rack up the kills, the requirement for which increases with each upgrade level. The base jet is fragile but speedy, with a powerful and reliable dual cannon (bullets), followed by an extension giving you ramming abilities, more armor and replacing the bullets with homing missiles. Keep on killing, and you’ll get yourself a flying tank: slow, but resilient and powerful. Still not enough? Have yourself a big flashy laser and even more missiles! Of course, the tank doesn’t stay on forever. After soaking enough damage, your jet pops out of the tank wreckage, ranks up, gaining extra damage, and a bit of armor as well. With the current update, you can upgrade to a maximum level of level 5 (MK-V), and will no longer go past this level, greatly cutting down the time between upgrades. As a plus, now it’s much easier to get the laser turret on your tank, thanks to the increased armor every time you receive the tank upgrade.

As for the combo, well, imagine Luftrausers, but it goes way beyond 20. Destroy enemies to increase combo, damage enemy parts and projectiles (missiles and mines) to sustain it. Gotta keep it going, or you’re risking yourself with your leaderboard position, or maybe your hardware (uh oh). Sometimes it’s better to leave some jets around to fill the combo up in case the big guys are gone. One of the more frustrating parts of the game at first, you’ll easily find yourself chaining naturally once the familiarity settles in. It may take a while though!

Do note that the upgrades are all automatically applied, so keep an eye on the upgrade status so that your precious chain won’t be broken as you upgrade during which you can’t attack or move freely.

The leaderboard is what you’ll be looking at once you boot up the game. FA is built around this leaderboard that resets every 36 hours. A higher place gives more rank, experience points if you will. Occasionally you’ll run into super hardcore and talented players than get million scores like a walk in the park... don’t fret. You’ll get your chance.

Ultimately, the difficulty comes from mastering the scoring system itself: sustaining chains by taking apart enemies effectively, avoiding enemy fire, clever use of the tank, and quickly dealing with Carriers before it’s too late.

This might be the part that turned me off initially - it takes a lot of time to get used to the controls, and scoring. But it pays off. It feels good when it clicks. It’s such a simple concept with a hell lot of depth.


[h1]Graphics and sounds[/h1]
FA is no flashy triple A madness. It’s a simplistic game, both in graphics and sounds. But hey, it works really well!

Graphics wise, FA has that low-poly look, but with its own charm. It's very easy to tell what is dangerous and what isn't. The enemies are cool and varied in their designs, having details down to the rotating engines. The background seemed quite bland at first, but it doesn't outshine the foreground elements where the action takes place.

The UI is minimalistic but effective. To the point where sometimes there’s no UI at all. When things get busy though, you’ll see why it’s kept this way. Focus is the key.

The sounds - mmh, some hate it. I used to be with them, but it makes a lot of sense now that I’ve had way too much time with this game. Explosions don’t sound crispy enough, but your chain does. Gotta keep it going, told ya.

Music is short and catchy. For a game like this, the soundtrack sets you right in the mood for action while not grabbing much of your attention. If you wanna feel more epic, you’ll find a setting that does just that. Give it a try ;]


[h1]Overall enjoyment[/h1]
It’s funny. My initial impression with FA was not very positive. In fact, I hated it. Mainly because of the frustration when breaking a chain (makes you say the F word quite a lot). Or failing to predict the enemy positions. Or running straight into projectiles like an idiot.

Messing up in this game really frustrates me. But moments like pulling off a slick dodge, saving a chain, and taking apart Carriers swiftly, these are what makes the whole experience worth it. It really does feel rewarding, once you get to it. This game is a slow burn. Take your time, if you can’t do it now, try again later. Learn from the mistakes. Experience builds up. And hard work pays off! Now look at your run time... Does it look like a coffee break experience to you? *Cough*

FA is something you could spend as little as only a few minutes on every day, but keep coming back because it’s just so addictive, despite the frustration. At its core, it is after all an arcadey shmup. It’s definitely not for everyone, but give it a try! Maybe you’ll like it.

I’m proud to be part of the testers of the recent update - even after all these years, the developer is still actively improving the game. That is some serious dedication you won’t find even in some AAA titles. FA is a much different game now than it initially was a few years back. It has come a long way. Thanks Morfeo!


That’s all! I hope my review is helpful to you in deciding your purchase. Thanks for checking out my review ;]

review:
[h1]Just one more run… just one more.[/h1]

Furious Angels really shines after a few sessions, once you become comfortable with the core mechanics. The game managed to drop me into that rare meditative state that a select few titles manage to pull off. It creates a perfect motion of being asked for actions to be performed faster and faster until you aren't directly in control anymore, while really you are actually interacting with the game on a more intuitive level.

Your performance, beyond a personal sense of mastery, is recorded on a daily leaderboard. The leaderboard is reset frequently, and a fresh combination of enemy waves is available every few days. In short this is an extremely fun game, really easy to pick up but hard to master.

And at full price or even a sale I would definitely recommend you try this out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134282054', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1694807400}
review:
Nice arcade-y top-down dogfighter with great visual style, cinematic effects and controls, all of which add to its minimalist charm. The combat feels smooth and the upgrades are powerful while being varied, which prompts tactical changes as you progress through an diverse list of enemies. There's a daily leaderboard which is a nice touch and the achievements have a range of difficulties making it more of a challenge to collect them. It runs great on my machine at max settings but that is to be expected of a game of this technical complexity.

In terms of criticisms; I would like to play it offline - you can, but it runs painfully slow between lives, probably due to the game trying to update the leaderboards. Games can become repetitive so it would also have been nice to see a bigger variety in map backgrounds (maybe procedurally generated?) and a few different gamemodes/objectives.

Otherwise a great arcade game that is definitely worth the price, especially on sale. For new players I would recommend reading the [TIP] at the bottom of a match report because they are key to understanding the game and help pick it up when you return after a break.

review:
[b]EDIT: Nearly four months later still playing daily. Still definitely recommend.[/b]

[h1]Great fun![/h1]

I've had this on my wishlist for a year or so and decided to pick it up in the Steam summer sale. I'm glad I did. This game is a blast. I love arcadey games, and have always had a soft spot for twin stick shooters. If you want some fast and easy fun, you won't go wrong picking this up.

So you are a fighter protecting your mothership from a variety of invading flying machines. After every so many kills your ship will upgrade itself (which looks really cool) and you'll have better firepower. It has a low poly, kinda geometric landscape which looks great but there is a lot of fine detail on the different ships. The camera is good, and it does some awesome close-ups at times when something cool happens. And don't forget online leaderboards!

I've gotta say as well, that this game has top notch production value. It's normally $5, and I've paid much more for games that don't look as good as this one. Everything in the game looks cool and "clean" from the fonts to the look of the leaderboards to the landscapes to the ships. If I ever made a game, I'd use the aesthetics of this one as my template.

[b]11/10 BUY IT NOW![/b]

review:
Controls are imprecise and feel very loose, and the upgrades aren't great either. You go from a single shot, to semi-homing missiles (though the range is meagre), to a large tank with a spreadshot slowly-rotating turret, and finally to a (still tank) with a laser that feels like you've gone back to the first stage (and you lose your spreadshot). Bumping up the Marks, it doesn't really feel like your damage gets much better, and you're doubly done for if you do this when a carrier comes in.

Lots of little things add up to make this too frustrating to wholeheartedly recommend.

review:
I don't write many Reviews. 

I think most Games do not deserve, or need my opinion. 
And I usually don't feel well as an advertisement writer. 
But this one game is different. For me, this is a hidden Gem.

This is the only game i play everyday for 5-10 minutes. Since more then a Year. 
No other game got me hooked like this. I think I can say I like it a bit.
Maybe it is just a me-thing. Maybe it appeals just to my personal taste.

It is arcade-y, and in a way that makes it great ... I love the Explosions.
The graphics look simple. I like the minimalism. It makes it very clear and pure.
But it has a lot of depth. In the way you upgrade, your timings, how you fly.
And it is unforgiving. If you make mistakes you pay for them right away.
Yet it is so casual that you don't ever get angry. You just play another round.

The game gives every day a random Challenge, with different waves of enemies.
And there are daily leader-boards and Achievements.
Its addicting, but in a good way.

Jets.
Enjoy the Explosions.
Bombers - Rockets!
Circling - Find your Rhythm.
Scorpions.
Miners - Don't fail to Evade.
Raptor!
Kill the Carriers.
Impostor.
Upgrade your Ship.
Tank.
Lasers.
Repeat.
...
Fly fast and keep the Streak.
You will always die.
...
High Score.

I think many more people should play this hidden gem.
And its so cheap, you have no excuse not to.
Please play the game, and beat my score. 

Good Luck.

review:
Клон Asteroids с наворотами. Вместо войны с делящимися камнями здесь враги стреляют. Врагов несколько типов, отличающихся манерой движения и поведением прожектайлов. Все враги по какой-то причине похожи на видеокарты.
Сюжета нет. Миссий тоже. Набиваешь очки, чтоб попасть в ежедневную таблицу лидеров. Игроков мало, потому попадание в первую двадцатку при первом запуске, когда пробуешь управление, вначале вызывает недоумение, а потом разочарование.
Управление с геймпада хуже, чем управление с мыши.
Музыка безлика, но не бесит.
Игра не плохой таймкиллер, но своей цены она скорее не стоит и тратить время можно на вещи куда более занимательные, например смотреть в стену.

Get hit too many times in upgraded ships you get booted back down to lower level ships.
Get hit too often in lower level ships you die.
You can stop firing to "heal" but you can't stop firing because they're trying to kill you and your beloved carrier.

So again... git gud.

review: This game is easy to pick up and tough to master--but it's fun and addictive. It's definitely worth the price and, if you don't always have a lot of time to get into a game, it's a good choice to pick up and just blast things for a bit--although I've found myself playing game after game trying to get my score a little higher, trying to survive just a little longer. The flight mechanics feel natural, and the fact that the ship doesn't instantly reach a desired speed and that speed affects ability to change course quickly make it fun and challenging. If you're looking for an enjoyable action game to pick up, Furious Angels is a good choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052707118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1550333512}
review:
It's Unity based, so the game is haunted by bad performance. Sadly this isn't the only negative aspect of the game ...

The music is rather bland and uninspired, the sound effects are dull and not rewarding. Furthermore the whole mixing of effects and music is dismissed on this one. The art design may look promising, but in reality it's rather bland and it looks like a quick job to me.

The game itself does not feature any levels, so it's just you starting from the beginning each and every time. That's really sad because it could have been easily converted into so much more. The controls are good but you won't have much time to enjoy, because the difficulty is rather unbalanced with its one hit deaths and no saving of your progress whatsoever.

On top of that I think the flight theme doesn't fit the genre overall. Maybe if it had been for a helicopter or even a B17 style plane, but with a jet? Nope, just doesn't do it. If you want to play a good top down shooter with dual stick mechanics, there are many others to prefer here on Steam.  From the bottom of my heart I'd recommend "Neon Chrome" to you.

review:
Furious Angels  is a super fun game that is a little too hollow.

The game has so much potential and room to grow.
What we have is a Shoot 'em up that is intensely fun, addictive and challenging. You simple can;t get enough of the actual gameplay which really makes the game a gem, however all the game has to offer is skirmish 'mode' no actual campaign or levels or even multiplayer, the skirmish mode is tied to leaderboards but that alone isn't enough, the game would of been so much better and more fulfilling if it had some modes or even some form of story and goals.

As it stands the game has excellent gameplay, the graphics behind the game is amazing and it compliments the game itself very well. The price for the game isn't expensive either but i still feel the game would of been much better if it had some more content. As it stands i recommend the game solely because it looks good and feel good but it really does lack some much needed in game content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068720036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1672097207}
review:
Jeu très intéressant, dont le concept a été rarement vu mais a existé (notamment dans les années 80), Furious Angels ne réclame pas un gros pc mais toutefois une vraie carte graphique (et pas une puce intégrée, ayant essayé le jeu avec deux configurations). Des accents de Time Pilot, ce jeu qui a bercé un temps ma jeunesse, sur arcade puis avec une conversion sur Commodore 64 plutôt bonne même si moins véloce que l'originale, Furious Angels propose donc de détruire tout ennemi sur 360 degrés tout en protégeant le vaisseau mère.
Le plus dur est évidemment de protéger le vaisseau (ou ce que j'en ai compris) car les ennemis arrivent, nombreux. Mais il s'agit surtout de vous protéger vous.
Simple et très bien réalisé, ce shoot-them-up "défensif" saura vous maintenir, avec des parties courtes mais intenses et, pour peu que vous avez une carte graphique digne de ce nom, vous permettra de jouer en résolution maximale avec une vue de petits vaisseaux cependant bien précis.
Vous commencerez petit et vous finirez, si vous y arrivez, dans un gros vaisseau, au fur et à mesure que vous vaincrez des ennemis en une seule partie, afin de devenir plus puissant progressivement.
Un modèle de développement indépendant à soutenir, pour tous ceux qui apprécient les shoot-them-up.

review:
This is a weird recommendation - this game gets a thumbs-up, but I'm also conflicted about it.

It's like playing a single level over, and over, and that's it.  The game-play IS super fun, but after about 90 minutes of doing the exact same thing, you haven't just seen it all - you've seen it all 20+ times!

"Levels" - there's exactly 1.  And that is your mothership floating in place, doing nothing, while you defend it.  There are variously colored backgrounds.  When you blow up an enemy ship it falls to the ground and bounces off the terrain below, btu that's it.

Waves - they're always the same.  The only randomization is the direction from which a portion of a wave will come.  There will always 

Stability - it's perfectly stable.  Your mouse will lag as it loads, and that's a silly oversight, but once in game everything is smooth, and the graphics are beautiful.  It has leaderboards, and achievements.

Variety - Horribly lacking and what it desperately needs.  Add additional upgrades  you can toggle.  Add upgrade choices.  Add the ability to collect dropped weapons from enemies.  Add mothership abilities.  Add SOMETHING.  The base game is just so good, but it's not at all fleshed out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054594389', 'num_games_owned': 865, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1701526607}
review:
[h1]I have not played such a superb Arcade Game since the days of R-Type and Sidearms back on coin-ops in the 80s.[/h1]

[b][i]A rare thing to hear from me, but this is a buy full price game, screw waiting for Steam Sale. I'd say oneof  the holiest of compliments you could.[/i][/b]

A superb arcade game, this top view shooter provides incredibly satisfying gameplay. You are the last surviving fighter desperately protecting the only [i]Air Carrier[/i] left in your fleet. Your sessions are short and....[u]Furious[/u] as you carve your way through ever increasing waves of enemy. You will not survive the day, and neither will your score! Daily wipes of High Scores give a fighting chance to all of us to get into the top 100, a great gimic!

I had to look carefully to remind myself this was a 22mb download as the guys have used some very clever vector type graphics to immerse us in a very pretty little world that lights up with exploding mayhem rather quickly! On that note, this will run on pretty much anything, and still look great. The sound effects are meaty and the music is inspiring, perfectly executed.

Controls are simple, WASD + Mouse or use your controller (advise mouse though!) or even a combination works. You zip around using some classic circle strafing for most of the enemies and head on bashing as your ship upgrades through four stages from [i]Jet Fighter[/i] to [i]Flying Tank[/i]. Refraining from firing for a second allows your craft to auto heal and keep you in the fight, while it also reloads your missile banks if present. This provides incentive for tactical play at times as apose to mad arcade mayhem, a good balance!

All in all, your session never will last longer than 3-6 minutes. But using combo's and slightly different tactics each run makes this a very more-ish game and I can guarantee struggles to stop mashing the "play again" button. Every day, the leaderboard resets and the format of the enemy waves changes, providing endless challenges and if you suck today, tomorrow you might impress your peers and hit that top 100! Satisfying, fun, simple and addictive as all hell.

 - [b]An incredible addition to your library![/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198015267128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1058, 'last_played': 1548276846}
review:
Ah furious angels, you could have been so much more! It killed me a little to hit the not recommend button (and it is a close call between the two) but at its price point, I think it has just a few too many flaws to be worth the money. 

[b]What flaws? (this is also the stuff I wish I'd known before buying): 

1) The game has a chronic lack of content. [/b]

[b]Enemies[/b]

There are 6 enemy types; the jet (a fast moving basic swarm enemy), the bomber (a slower more substantial missile enemy), the scorpion (basically a floating tank), the miner (which deploy fast homing mines (basically another, but bigger missile boat) and the imposer (which also happens to be your upgraded form). Oh and of course the enemy carriers which appear from time to time. 
I personally hate the reuse of player models for enemies so I'd consider there to be 5 enemy types, all of which you will encounter in the first 10 mins of play. 

[b]Maps[/b]

All the maps are essentially identical, a wide open space with a different colour, low poly floor. They actually look pretty good, apart from where there appears to be issues with the floor mesh so you can see through it :S

[b]Your upgrades[/b]

Your fighter has just 3 upgraded forms; one with missiles, a tank variant and a laser variant of the tank.Upgrade forms are lost when you die in either of the tank forms (returning you to the first form) and if you die in the first two forms you loose the game. 
There is no permanent progression. 

All in all after about an hour or so of play, the game can start to feel stale. 

[b]2) Lack of real support (support beyond bug fixes).[/b]

The patches in the last few months have added no real content to the game. In December two maps were added (which in all honestly isn't anything to write about). At the moment this game feels a little like a fire and forget in terms of content. 

[b]3) Cheaters[/b]

One of the appeals of the game is the fact everyone is ranked each day and then the boards are reset. A fun idea which has bought me back a couple of days in a row now. 
Unfortunately it seems either I'm fairly terrible at the game or the top few players (who all have a strangely low number of kills) are doing something a little dodgy. 

For example;today entry into the daily top ten came at around 9k points (which is pretty challenging to get) and then most people are clustered around the 9-12kmark. Then you have the top couple of players who are on 50/60k+ points (while only having a two hundred kills and only reaching the second jet weapon upgrade). Even if you chained practically every kill, it just doesn't seem feasable. 

I could be completely wrong, but that feels totally wrong. If these people are cheating (it seems there is a trainer/hack available on a Russian forum) then that really hurts one of the main appeals of this game. 

[b]Now though, it would be pretty unfair if I didn't say what I liked about the game[/b]

[b]1)[/b] The art style is simplistic but has a real charm with what it does. I know some people feel the maps are bland (and no doubt they are simple) but I think they are perfect for the style of the game. 
The designs of the enemy ships are nicely done, and differ from each other well. The design on the player ships is a little disappointing for me - there are so many potential cool designs for a futuristic fighter that didn't involve taking a modern looking jet and jamming a turret on the back :( (but hey that's my personal preference)! 

[b]2)[/b] Destruction of enemy ships and the physics of them falling to the earth is fantastic. For the Scorption, Miner, Impostor and Carrier you have to blast apart the engines/hard points to destroy the ship as a whole. This feels great, and watching the ship tumble out of the sky after you knock out engines is beautiful. 

[b]3)[/b] The game mechanics are also simple but well done and  there are a few little tricks you can use to improve your game (like the turret turns faster when you aren't boosting). 

This game has a kernel of something really fun at its core, and could be really great. It needs more of all the content [b](developer > apart from maps, don't waste time with more maps).[/b] Even just a handful more enemy ship and more of your own upgrade options (dare I wish for an upgrade tree where you choose your own upgrades?!) would really breathe a huge amount more life into this game. 
Unfortunately looking at recent patches, it seems real content is perhaps unlikely. I really hope I'm wrong and I'll be keeping an eye on this game just in case! For now though, it is a thumbs down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077583212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1682705315}
review:
I like Furious Angels.

It doesn't do anything [i]spectacularly[/i] original or amazing, but it takes what it is, boils it down, distills it, removes all the fluff and filler, and just focuses on that, and it does it well.

Fly your jet. Shoot other jets. Die. Repeat. 

There is no complex weapon upgrade tree, there's no XP system to progress from scrappy rust bucket to chromed war machine. There aren't procedurally generated enemies with ten thousand possible combinations. Just you, your jet (in its three forms), several enemies, and a boss type enemy. What makes it engaging is how you choose to prioritize and deal with them when your screen is full of enemies, without it resorting to full on frantic bullet hell. 

My biggest fault with the game is the audio. The sound effects lack a lot of oompf and feels more like you're popping bubblewrap than making things explode. And likewise the music feels anaemic and doesn't (IMHO) do a good job of getting you into the "zone".

So, have a look at the video above, and if that tickles your fancy, I'd recommend giving the game a go. Just don't expect a 60 hour deal with a fleshed out story, multiplayer lobbies, crafting systems and economies and sandboxes and and and. The game is exactly what it says on the tin: a $5 score attack shooter.

review:
The game is pure rogue-like bullet hell eye-candy, the graphics and physics are both awesome but can get repetitive quick, mainly because of the permadeath factor. An important thing to note here is that your progress does not get saved. Also, I really don't like the tank upgrade, I would gladly skip it if I could. But no, I must have it at all costs and then become slow like a slug while being stormed by mechanical (kamikaze) fruitflies ships and whatnot all around, hoping to get the laser upgrade. Also, the bombs are pretty hard to avoid. 

Another thing to note is that the game is infuriatingly hard, so now I can kinda see why it's called Furious Angels! It's because the game makes us furious, while we fly like angels. 

I also like the game, because it's one of those games that look beautiful, play beautiful and I can listen to videos of people talking stuff in the background without missing anything since the sounds aren't really the best. Although it doesn't really matter in such a game, you can listen to whatever you want to while playing, and this is more of a bonus to me. I recommend this game to anyone, but be aware, it's repetitive because it has permadeath and you need to start always from the beginning... and it's hard because it has mechanical fruitflies!

I was looking for a game like Devil Daggers, but I wasn't into the 1990s PC graphics aesthetic. I learned about Furious Angels and saw that it provodes a similar experience as an endless shooter. I prefer the low poly sci-fi look to Devil Daggers' Quake style. For the $3.98 I paid during the dall 2017 Steam Sale, this was a no brainer; easy to learn but difficult to master. As an endless mob rush game, you can't ever "win" - eventually you'll be overrrun with mobs and killed. The point of this game is to see how many waves of mobs you can destroy before you meet your ultimate demise and compare what you';ve done to everyone else playing that day. The sequence of enimeies changes daily, so ever day that you play the game, it'll be a little different. 

Furious Angels isn't a technically demanding game so you should be able to run it in some form on a toaster. Giev it a try while it's on sale - you won't be disappointed. I can't descrbe how impressed I am with this little gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025492428', 'num_games_owned': 632, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1706762339}
review:
it's basically luftrausers with some interesting tweaks.

just like luftrausers the objective is not to die, and the game will try it's damnest to do it. your vessel is made of paper, amd the game throws buckets of enemies on you. you rarely last more than five minutes each game session. also the control scheme is pretty much the same, and the basic gameplay - shoot everyone, don't get shot, stop shooting to recover health.

very different from luftrausers, however, is everything else. 

progression wise, instead of relying on unlockables external to the gameplay that tweak gameplay aspects, it's progression happens during each match. bad news is no progress is permanent, except your rank on the leaderboards. good news is that it gives an extra edge during each gameplay session - every upgrade a breath of air, making you grit your teeth until the next one kicks in.

the enemy scaling and distribution are different from luftrausers too - there it was more organic. in this game, enemies come in very defined waves. the game even informs the types of enemies and how many of each, which is nice, because there's a bit of strategy added to the gameplay with this information. but the game doesn't stop spawning waves until you finish the last - they stack if you're not quick enough, and you probably won't be.

one possible down side to this game is that there isn't a lot of content. it's a score chaser after all, you play it to get good at it and take a crack at the leaderboards.

graphics and sound wise it's ok. the game looks good, and it's music and sound are basic, but they do their job. nothing to write home about it, but not bad either.

all in all, it's a great little game. very gripping and satisfying for a score chaser game. If you enjoy this kind of game, I recommend it greatly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028886970', 'num_games_owned': 1133, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1522222808}
review:
I think it’s fairly obvious if you’d like this game or not from it’s description. So, I’ll elaborate on the one aspect that stuck out to me that’s different from other arcade shooters: The sound design. 

Originally, I didn’t enjoy the sound design. It just felt off for the only real effect to be the soft “pop” of your own gunfire when fighting upwards of twenty aircrafts. But, as I progressed further on repeat runs, I came to appreciate this single, solitary sound. Things may go wrong, multiple ships will fill the screen, tens of missiles will lockon to you, mines will hurtle past, the Mothership will be under attack, all the while you will always “pop, pop, pop…” at each enemy with brief pauses in between, as if you’re coming up for air. This effect is even better when you get to the third stage of your ship. You now have a powerful turret which creates a sound much like rain hitting an umbrella you’re standing under. It’s a very pleasing sound. 

To take this one step further, it’s important to remember what this game is: A score attack game with no end except for when you inevitably lose. And I find this inevitability is highlighted by the paired-down sound design. You don’t need deafening explosions and gunfire to warn you of danger because you already know there is danger. No matter how good of a pilot you are, no matter long you dodge missiles, you will lose. And that’s the beauty of Furious Angels and what makes it very easy to sink into, or out of, throughout the day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000919706', 'num_games_owned': 2234, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1510650787}
review:
I really wanted to enjoy it, but I don't. I also feel pretty bad about this, because as a game it's alright: it runs, it's stable, it does what it says on the tin. But it's just not that fun.

The one gun on your ship feels anaemic and weak, and the first upgrade doesn't actually feel that noticeable in terms of your speed or the power of your weapon.

The second upgrade is the tank, which has its own problems as it's slow and it's huge so everything hits you, and by the time you've built up enough of a combo to trigger the tank upgrade there'll be a lot of enemies and projectiles to be hit by, so you don't get to enjoy the beefed-up firepower for very long. It also triggers automatically, so how useful you'll find it depends entirely on when it happens.

There's a laser upgrade I can't comment on as I've not managed to get up to that level yet, and I don't really feel compelled to try. Apart from the waves changing daily, that's all there is to the game. There are no other modes, nothing else to try out or to keep your interest after your first few rounds. It plays alright I guess, though momentum feels a little weird and it's nowhere near as responsive as it needs to be (certainly it controls nothing like Luftrausers).

I feel like if this was an Early Access title I'd definitely hold on to it, as there's a lot of potential for a good game here. But it's not an Early Access title, and what's here doesn't feel like it's enough to justify a purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970823102', 'num_games_owned': 379, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 1822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1624008142}
review:
Furious Angels ist in seiner Einfachheit genial, ist fordernd und macht richtig Laune.

Man steuert einen kleinen Kampfjet und muss sowohl am Leben bleiben als auch das große Trägerschiff von dem man gestartet ist verteidigen. Wenn man nicht schießt, regeneriert der Jet erlittene Schäden wieder weg. Nach bestimmten Abschusszahlen erhält man Upgrades. Dann schießt man zuerst zielsuchende Raketen (mit beschränkter Reichweite) von einem etwas größerern Jet und bei nochmaligem Upgrade verwandelt sich unser Jet in ein noch größeres und langsameres, dafür aber haltbarerers Kriegsschiff mit massiverer Feuerkraft. Diese dritte Upgradestufe ist dann auch eine Art Hülle, die wieder abgeworfen wird, wenn sie zu viel Schaden erleidet und dann hat man wieder den normalen Jet, womit das Upgradespiel von vorn los geht.

Es gibt nich besonders viele Gegnertypen, das macht aber nichts, weil sie so zahlreich auftreten, dass man eh nur wild rumballert und versucht selber nicht getroffen zu werden. Außerdem decken die vorhanden Typen alles nötige ab: schnelle Jets, weniger Schnelle Bomber mit Zielsuchraketen, langsame Tanks, sehr langsame und dafür fett gepanzerte  Zielsuchminenleger und Träger mit Großkanone gegen unseren Träger.

Einziges Manko (aus meiner Sicht natürlich) ist der Sound. Weder Waffen noch Explosionen klingen besonders wuchtig, was ich sehr schade finde. Und die Musik ist leider ziemlich unspektakulär angesichts der Action.

Fazit:
FA ist zwar nur ein kleine Spiel für Zwischendurch (pro Runde ca. 2-5 Minuten, mit Skill natürlich auch länger möglich). Es macht Gaudi und entwickelt durch seinen fordernden Schwierigkeitsgrad eine ähnliche Nur-noch-eine-Runde-Suchtwirkung wie beispielsweise Devil Daggers.
Ich hab im Sale knapp unter 4 Euro bezahlt und bereue den Kauf in keinster Weise. 
Daher: Klare Empfehlung für Zwischendurch!

author: {'steamid': '76561198327364259', 'num_games_owned': 1008, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 1300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1559197235}
review:
[b] 《Furious Angels》[/b] 
是一款画风简洁的飞行射击游戏
与其说是飞行射击其实就是移动射击
游戏内容介绍下面的朋友说的已经够多了
没什么好补充的==

游戏的整体操作非常简单
WASD移动 左键射击 右键喷气
停止开火可以自动维修机体
玩家可以攻击指定数量的敌机进行短暂升级
初始等级：发射机炮
第二等级：带有小幅度追踪效果的导弹
第三等级：空中坦克发射密集的机炮弹幕
第四等级：强力的激光+大量导弹
但空中坦克模式
侧面装甲损坏了并不能维修==

游戏本体的意义应该是保护地图中间的飞船
并击毁前来攻击的敌机来比拼分数
然而如楼下所说
每四波左右会刷出一艘空母来攻击你要保护的飞船
每次数量会+1
就是说第二次刷新空母的数量为二（以此类推）
一般情况下 
挺不过第3波空母的进攻
因为它们是无视玩家直接攻击飞船的

关于成就
这游戏基本都是堆叠式的成就
动辄击落一万敌机才能完成
而且最令人发指的成就
要数在排行榜前十名待上几天→.→
反正到现在我也没能达成全成就

优点：
+画风清新
+操作简单

缺点：
-缺少BGM
-模式单一
-内容枯燥
-无法离线运行
-强制结束游戏

[h1]不断重复的挑战模式无比单一
不能挂卡 恶心的成就
而且不能离线模式 
尽管上手简单 打开即玩
但我还是不推荐购买这款游戏

author: {'steamid': '76561198080979495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1561738822}
review:
[h1] Firewatch спустя 2000 лет [/h1]

Ну что же, все ачивки получены, кайф доставлен. Перед вами маленькая, но очень интересная игра, которую не стыдно иметь в своей библиотеке. Furious Angels - это бесконечный шутер с летающими танками, лидербордом, разнообразием волн каждый день и апгрейдами. Попо дробней)

• [b] Геймплей. [/b] Доска почета сбрасывается  на следующий день. Ваш ранг в общей таблице обновляется, волны меняются, каждый день волна будет содержать разных противников.  Вы взлетаете с «матери» маленькой мухой и в поте лица начинаете оборонять свой авианосец. На вас прут бомбардировщики, мелкие и быстрые истребители, толстые минеры, точные Скорпионы и истребители «Раптор» похожие на модель вашего кораблика. По мере отбивания волн, наша «Муха» апгрейдиться, что дает нам боле толстые типы кораблей и мощней вооружение. Вершиной апгрейда является космический танк стреляющий ракетами и лазерами. 

Убили? Игра закончилась, жмем рестарт. Если вы смогли проапргейдиться до уровня танка, при достижении минимального количества ХП, вы не умрете, а катапультируетесь на мухе v 2.0 и так далее. Версия кораблика дает вам больше урона с пушек. Управлять корабликом можно даже одной рукой. Но, я по привычке использовал WASD и мышь. С каждой волной врагов становиться всё больше и больше. Спустя минут 10 игры, это всё начинает напоминать Crimsonland.  Спасает то, что если вы получили «маслину», желательно убрать палец с кнопки «Огонь», за несколько секунд, корабль отхилится. Отлетели далеко от «Мамы»? Прилетают 2-3 вражеских «Папы» и устраивают фильм «Отцы жарят мать во все дырки. Без регистрации и смс». Апгрейды, точность, дистанция, реакция… всё это потребуется для того чтобы попасть в топы.  Но, чаще всего в топах сидят люди, которые накручивают себе очки с помощью Artmoney и это печально. Обязательно обращайте внимание на ранг и количество сбитых врагов. Тогда будет понятно…  действительно ли человек старался, чтобы туда попасть или же юзнул прогу.

• [b] Звук. [/b]Ничего особенного. 2-3 трека, взрывы и тра-та-та-та.

• [b] Графика. [/b] Именно из-за скриншотов, я решил попробовать эту игру. Сделана на Unity красиво и минималистично. Долго не мог вспомнить, где я е уже видел эти острые углы и яркую палитру. Оу «Firewatch»… вот куда судьба завела Генри, всё из-за женщины. 

• [b] Ачивки. [/b] Веселые, не тяжелые, за исключением 3-х. 
- Достигнуть 2-го аргейда корабля, с точностью 50%, 100 раз

author: {'steamid': '76561198023825035', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1529860345}
review:
This game has such potential to be a truly great breakout title, but I feel like the devs are just not getting it. I want so badly for this game to be worth my time. It's a gorgeous, it has a unique feel, and it's doing some interesting things. If it weren't for a few key issues, I would easily spend $20-$30 for something like this.

The first time I played this game, I returned it. But I provided some feedback to the devs. I've now given it a second chance because after reading some of the updates, it looked like maybe they fixed some of these issues. But now I see that the fixes were really minor. There are core, fundamental things about this game that just make it an aggravating, impossible, and unsatisfying experience. The cool or potentially cool things about this game are constantly undermining each other.


FUN.

As a player, you can't appreciate the action of an action game and the results of your efforts if you never get to see or hear your enemies explode. This is an action game, right? Then why are most of the enemies always off-screen and I never even get to see or even HEAR them explode? All I get is a meaningless number that pops up next to my cursor too fast to comprehend, with no context whatsoever, and it isn't supported by any on-screen HUD or helpful information of any kind. And as a bonus, these enemies are shooting at me with homing missiles that I also can't see or hear, and by the time I do see them, my ship is too slow or set in it's momentum to do anything about it if they happen to be on the perfect f***ing trajectory. And, honestly, enemies have homing missiles within the first 30-60 seconds of the game is ridiculous. Why would I play a game where I know I'm very likely going to die within the first minute and a half no matter how good I get at it?

All the foundational principles of what makes video games FUN (faster gratificaion/achievements than in real life, savoring the details and results of your actions, watching your personal skill get better, escapism by immersing yourself into a different reality) have been completely shot in this game.

IMMERSION.

A good video game, like any good movie or book, allows you to escape your reality and enjoy a different one for a while, where achievements come a little faster, and you get a little more satisfaction for your work. But with this game, you know the entire time that you're playing a video game. You never get to suspend disblief long enough to have real fun. 

The first reason is because you can't see anything the whole time. You're attention is constantly going to the edges of the screen.

The second reason is that even if that blindness mechanic was intentional, you can't stay alive long enough to appreciate it somehow. You're constantly trying to hear if you happened to hit an enemy ship or maybe get lucky enough to hear an enemy ship fire a weapon; but instead you hear the music because those sound effects are so faint. And some of those songs have beats that sound confusingly similar to the in-game sound effects.



This game is constantly shooting itself in the foot. 

Because a shmup where the sound was more important that the visuals might actually be pretty interesting. But then they choose songs that make that muddle the sound effects. The songs are really cool and moody and interesting, but they're in the way. 

This game has gorgeous visuals, but you never get to see the ships. 

The visuals and the music in the beginning establish this slow, intentional mood and pacing, and then the ship has to do these banks and slower more intential maneuvers which add to that. But then the game punishes you for getting into that mood by cutting your visual, hiding information, making the sound effects too quiet to hear, adn throwing enemies at you that are better than you in every way.

I could go on and on and on. This game has a lot of potential and some interesting ideas, but it feels like there was no one clear vision for why all of these things are designed like this. So instead it's just this disjointed thing whose individually creative parts just get in each other's way and ruin the overall experience.

The value I got out of this is more of a luck-based soundtrack than a skill-based shooter.

I would love to be able to recommend it, but I just can't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198394692579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 80, 'last_played': 1612634211}
review:
I love twin-sticks, but I don't usually care for survival/score attack ones because they feel so limited.  Furious Angels is an exception.

Yes, each game will probably last five minutes or less.  Yes, there is no grand strategy involved.  Just reflexes and think-on-your-toes sort of tactics.  It is so very well executed though; probably the best game of its sort that I've played in a long time.

The basic mechanics are rock solid; the controls are smooth as silk, the difficulty ramps slowly and steadily because of a well-designed wave pattern and consistent upgrades.  If you dawdle, you can easily get overwhelmed in the early stages, but FA definitely rewards good play.  Though there is some luck involved, in what game is there not?

tldr: I can heartily recommend FA for any shoooter enthusiast, especially if you're looking for something you can pick up for five to ten minutes and then put right back down.  If that's not your bag, probably don't bother.  This is a niche game which fills its niche very, very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198290144620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 286, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1505317961}
review:
先说一下游戏的大致内容吧，移动飞行射击游戏，你们也看到了。
其次这游戏是用Unity引擎制作，2.5D（3D游戏+平面视角），安装包只有区区15MB，但内容不少，和破解组的压缩技术有得一拼。看容量你也知道了，游戏的内容简单粗暴，连教程和提示都没有。一进游戏就提示赶紧动动方向键开搞，后面就是就是射射射，射出你的激情……

游戏画面还行，有碰撞体积，有物理效果，而音乐方面则低调到几乎不存在。

游戏支持键鼠和手柄，键盘和鼠标操作方法不用说你也知道，无非就是方向键移动，鼠标锁定目标。
如果玩家想开打就按下前进键，然后小飞机会从航母起飞。WASD控制飞行方向，鼠标左键射击，右键喷射加速。游戏一开始敌人就会不停的刷，虽然有波次，但是程序可不管玩家有没有完全消灭掉那一波，时间一到下一波就来，动作慢一点敌人就越打越多。既然敌人那么能刷，玩家当然也能回血，只要不攻击机体就开始自行维修（回血）。游戏中玩家可以借助杀敌升级，如果玩家的飞机离自己的航母过远，敌方就会刷出一艘航母来暴打玩家的航母，玩家的航母一爆游戏也会结束。话说那敌方航母，不管你有没有出范围，后面都会刷一大堆，然后你的航母被打中之后还不会回血，真是强制结束游戏的节奏。
游戏中玩家可以借助杀敌来升级，一开始是小飞机，然后是稍大一点火力更强的轰炸机，再然后是行动缓慢体积庞大、可以和敌方舰船撞个稀巴烂的空中坦克，如果你运气好在坦克阶段刷够了人头，上面的炮会变成激光的。但是坦克一爆又会回到小飞机，只不过武器威力有所提升（Mk3小飞机的火力大概是Mk1坦克的水平），就这样循环往复。死了以后一切清零……

喵的别看宣传片那么屌爆，这游戏玩起来的感觉就和《几何战争》一样，不过容易一些。
首先这游戏最适合早泄型——反应极快的——玩家，如果你的反射弧不是那么发达，望还是酌情考虑一下。像我这种用脑子多过用反应的，玩这游戏也就勉强应付，被迫集中注意力和提升反应，玩起来一点不休闲，如果反应力不是维持在让我有点痛苦高水平最多就能杀入等级的第二阶段（Mk2）初期，1400分。如果你想玩得好就要不断练习，但是游戏内容很重复很乏味，我不是很推介。不过你要精通其实也不难，无非就是绕着目标打转，朝着你画出来的圆心一通乱射。
不管你玩得如何，我认为游戏大概会在5000-10000分之间结束，因为那时候就算你不死，你的航母也完蛋了。（我的最高记录是7245.44，所以你也别说我是玩不来才投反对的。）
话说了这游戏还要手眼协同，如果是手残型玩家和易眩晕群体还是尽早退散。不然控制的飞机和目标在那里甩呀甩、转呀转，肯定会受不了的。
我觉得这钱花在《掠食之翼》上还划得来。

如果是过关制的，难度循序渐进，玩家的飞机又能慢慢升级，我觉得这样设计应该还行。但是这游戏又无故事又无关卡，难度没得选，上来就是挑战模式和线上积分比拼……你当我吃这一套？史丹利你这混蛋，我还没蠢到吃这一套，刷刷刷很烦的。
这游戏偶尔拿来玩玩还可以，但如果你玩不好，那就会经常干重复活，游戏很容易乏味。

评分：6/10，牛逼哄哄的宣传片，勉勉强强的游戏。主要这游戏因为是小团队制作，已经改动无望了，提了意见没人回复，也只能摊手了。当然这在传统射击类游戏中算不错的，如果你喜欢这种类型，值得一玩，反正可以退款，只要别玩过头；）

PS：那么小巧的游戏也算难得，我还是会考虑回购的，毕竟现在资金流动审查比较严，如果是10元应该是可以接受的。

author: {'steamid': '76561197970359498', 'num_games_owned': 1696, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1599386607}
review:
There is no shortage of arcade style twin-stick shooters on Steam, we're all well aware of that.  Furious Angels adds another tally mark to that list.  However, while it doesn't take the genre or the core mechanics very far in any new direction, what it does add makes for a game that feels distinctly different from the thick soup of clunky similar games.

[h1]Furious Angles: Explodyo Drift[/h1]

The first thing I noticed after starting up the game, outside of the fact that you're thrown pretty much immediately in to the action, is that the flight mechanics force you to manage your movement with a lot of drift and curve compensation.  Rather than working on a principle of precision control like other twin-sticks, accelerating will create momentum in the corresponding direction, so if you attempt to turn, you won't immediately go that way, but rather make an arching curve dependent on your speed.  While you don't need to be worried about smashing in to the sides of the level like Geometry Wars, you do still need to be able to adjust to avoid the massive amount of enemy fire.  This comes in to play more as you encounter enemies with more damaging and precise weapons, as often a hit or two will be all it takes to bring your run to an abrupt end.  What this mainly did is make the game look much more fluid and play in a way that requires a bit more skill in maneuvering and dodging.  

Furious Angels seems as though it was designed with a goal of minimalism beyond all else.  From the very start you're given a menu that exists as text integrated into the game space at an angle, originally aligning itself with the carrier you take off from.  You can even effectively play the game using only a mouse.  There's also little in the way of a UI anywhere on the screen during gameplay.  Score gain floats away from destroyed enemies, upgrade countdowns and other pertinent information floats around your ship.  Even your ship health is a mystery as it is only indicated by some flashing that is incredibly easy to miss in the fast pace and explosive gameplay.  This certainly adds to the unique properties of the game, there are places that it is definitely missed. 

[h1]What might have been...[/h1]

While I am a fan of indie arcade games, and I find this game mechanically sound, it's hard to keep playing it solely to climb up the scoreboard.  Especially with how frustrating the upgrade system can be, given that each new upgrade slows you down in the process of giving you more armor and armament, meaning eventually you're just cannon fodder.  Yet, it seems like a game as well crafted as this is mechanically would have more overall content.  Something like permanent upgrades for your ship, or some sort of consumable.   Maybe cosmetic unlocks like new backgrounds, a night mode, skins, special game modes, or even just some variation in the order and components of each wave.  A game that has a gameplay loop that can still manage to keep me challenged and entertained even without the prospect of unlocks or rewards is impressive on its own, but with good additions that include things like that, it would be one I'd have a hard time putting down.  It's clear with the description of the game and the  current design that the developer has no intention of taking the game in this direction – it is as arcade as arcade can be.

[h1]Livid Cherub[/h1]

Furious Angels joins the elite club of games I can jump in and play for 10 or 15 minutes at a time and feel satisfied having done so.  It may not always be as fun as I wanted, and there's a really high chance I'll die to a random hit when I assumed I had more health than I did, but the simplicity really makes it addicting.  When you couple that with a reasonable price (easily under $5 on sale), Furious Angels earns a recommendation.  It's just one of those games that looks nice
 in a video and then you play it and understand why it manages to look fluid and action packed in every snippet.  

If you'd like to see more of my reviews, check out my curator page here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/EndyoGaming#curation

review:
A very entertaining arcade shooter best played in quick bursts. The player's goals are to stay alive, upgrade their craft by reaching certain numbers of kills, and protect their home carrier from ever-more-numerous packs of enemy carriers.

With the addition of the latest upgrade (1.3), Furious Angels is finally a game I can recommend without caveat. The firepower bonus consolation prize each time you survive losing the flying tank makes the difficulty ramp steadily for much longer than in previous versions. The decision to switch recharging missile salvos with a main weapon that simply fires a stream of missiles at the 2nd power-up level is also much appreciated.

review: This game has a surprising amount of depth for such simple mechanics. Rewarding the player for focus targeting specific components on large ships creates a nice David vs Goliath feel while disencentivising the normal strategy of flying away shooting backwards. The "Tank Mode" is a briliant way of implementing changing the game dynamic for an ultimate mode. While its firepower allows the player to output terrible distruction its lack of mobility prevents the player from avoinding incomming fire. Instead of an artifical time limit on the tank mode, the player can use it untill it has absorbed too much fire. The play sessions seema artificaly limited by the difficulty ramping up beyond what is physicaly possible to deal with. Also while the ambient music is nice the game is lacking in sound effects considering the ammount of shooting and explosions that are happening on screen. Overall this game is great value for the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023637559', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1501391857}
review:
Not a terrible game but lacks a lot of depth.. Developer responds quickly and there is a beta that allows for some screen fill options for larger displays. Got the game running at 4k now, buttery smooth. The game has some interesting mecanics and the way lives work, sort of feels like a shooter mixed with asteroids. It's actually quite fun, I just wish there were upgradable weapons, loadouts, etc. For that it has, basically you can upgrade into a slightly tougher ship that seems to do a bit more damage, and eventually a slow moving tank. You basically get ONE shot type, and some missles. That's it. I've seen games like Dragonia (porn twin stick game that noone should play) with tons of awesome meta, but really bad overall. If this game had that, it would be beautiful.

That's about it. If you stop firing for a second you get a missile barrage that you can let off making timed shots nice, but playing with the game pad makes accuracy a pain to get on the results. Overall I can reccomend the game as what it is, a fun time waster that has a developer that is looking to make a sequel. I'd hope to see some new mechanics added as load outs, weapon switch (multidimentional array, global settings, pretty simple stuff) just needs weapon effects, some already present such as a laser from the mother ships. Really would do well with some rpg or rouge lite mechanics, make this game so much more addicting. 

Also if you blow up in the first two modes (normal ship and heavier ship) you loose. If you blow up in tank you revert back to the speedy little ship to attempt to gain your tank all over. Sort of makes it hectic as you have tough enemies, so has some value. I don't know if the developer plans on doing anything to this game as comments of fancy stuff are waiting for a sequel, rather than improve upon the base to gain an audience to gain a sequel. 

Giving a thumbs up to help the ratings. Simple and fun but barebones. I want to see this game get bigger and add those rpg/rouge like mechanics. The gameplay would do well with it and make it so much better, so buy it so we can get a real full fledged game. For now, a fun time waster for work or when you just don't want to sit down and really get into anything but still want to blow shit up and throw your controller at the wall when you screw up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982940738', 'num_games_owned': 410, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1690826098}
review:
You know what? This game is a lot of fun! I don't normally go in for simple high score repetitive games, but I really enjoyed this and found myself saying "just one more turn" for easily 20 turns after I thought I'd quit.

There's a lack of meta game or anything, but its price is right. It's really fun to drop in for a few minutes.

There's another key here. There's a variety to the gameplay in the form of upgrades, and temporary "flying tank" bonus sections. The game you're playing from one minute to the next can be quite different, and each variation on your fighter feels different, too.

I really like the enmy design, graphical style, and especially the destruction mechanics on the larger ships. It feels great to blast off the engines on an enemy carrier and watch it topple. That's not to say it's easy. You still have to get to that side of your targeted enemy, which is sometimes impossible to do without dying, so you flee instead.

The game is hard, and one criticism is it basically devolves into circle strafting large groups of enemies eventually, but what game doesn't, frankly?

Another criticism is the sound. It's not bad but a little lacking. The music is great, but the SFX lag behind a little. Still, overall this is definitely worth a go and you'll find you keep coming back.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999428331', 'num_games_owned': 4960, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 265, 'last_played': 1516479285}
review:
I wish steam had a maybe option or something in between yes or no, because I would give this game a maybe, depending on how future updates come along. 
This game is very simple and that is good in some parts and hurts the game in others. The game resets the leader-boards every day which is an interesting take on a ranking system. The mouse-only control scheme is also pretty interesting and feels great (with the exception of poorly timed upgrades that can send you flying away from where you intended to be). The game has a minimalist UI (to the point of it not being there, really) The problems come with playing the game for too long. There are only seven different enemies, which means the randomized waves every day feature is barely noticeable. You often die because of something randomly firing from off screen and hitting you twice (miners are the most annoying). You'er weak and have no real way of telling how close to death you are (no health bar, your ship flashes when damaged, that's all). Bigger enemies can only be hit on weak spots, which makes sense, but everything that isn't a weak point blocks your shots from hitting other place on enemies (you can't even shoot through destroyed weak spots). There are only two upgrades, one adds missiles that work on a cool-down that you have no indication of (which is annoying because you have to stop shooting and start again to launch them), and the other turns you into a tank. The tank feels nice, it is slow and powerful and can ram a lot of enemies to death, but if it takes too much damage you become even slower and lose the ability to ram anything, wasting some of your time flying slowly waiting to lose the powerup. Then you star back from your base ship. Some achievements are either a grind or require you to be the best at this game, (looking at kill 10,000 jets, play for 10 days, and finish the day at rank #1) which is only really an issue if you are an achievement hunter. But they also feel set up to inflate game time.
At this point, I would only get this game if you really want to compete. I would wait to see what comes in the future or a sale if you really want it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020313592', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 576, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1492764233}
review:
[h1] Review - Furious Angels [/h1]
Review brought you by [url=www.savorquit.com]Save Or Quit[/url], visit us!

===

[h1] Overview [/h1]

Furious Angels is a top-down 2.5D classic shooter, with strongly competitive-oriented and skill-based gameplay. In this title, the player will be the only pilot left defending his carrier command ship against various hordes of enemies. Luckily, the carrier will give out upgrades every set number of enemies killed, to better fight off the onslaught. The objective, aside from staying alive and protecting the ship, is mostly scoring high combos to get a better position in the daily-resetting leaderboards, to compete with other pilots all over the world.

===

[h1] Gameplay Analysis [/h1]


[b] General Gameplay [/b]
The gameplay of Furious Angels uses a simple but well made and effective formula. There are just two goals, first is staying alive, and the second is to defend the carrier. While you are at it, make as many points as possible, so when you inevitably are overrun by enemies, your legend won't be forgotten! 

[b] Combat System [/b]
Combat system is based upon skill and reflexes mostly, you will have to improve after every run and understand the various attack patterns of enemies, to then calculate a good flight trajectory that will enable you to hit while dodging enemy bullets. Since the flight model is inertial, there is no quick turns and shooting, you will have to be more careful than normal or you will end up being a sitting duck and get blasted by a million of shots. There are two upgrades gained by killing enemies at regular intervals, first is Guided Missiles, which you can fire after a few seconds after you stop shooting your gun, and the second upgrade is Heavy Armor, which basically transforms your jet into a flying tank, until you get hit too much, then back to square one, basic jet. Also note that your ship can withstand a few bullet hits and will auto-repair in a short time, but to enable this you will have to hold fire while repairing.

[b] Content [/b]
There are resetting leaderboards and new enemy waves each day, a lot of achievements to pursue, though if we speak of content quantity there is not very much to be honest, enemy types are not many just 6 or 7, 2 upgrade types, no progression whatsoever, no other game modes. This game has not been developed with content in mind but with just one thing to do: compete in the global leaderboards, and in that it does pretty well. The main content is, definitely, the competition itself and the skill improvement you get after every run.

[b] Balancing [/b]
The game is fairly balanced, enemies are quite strong but again, skill will matter more than everything in this kind of game, i'd say the learning curve is not too steep, first times you will die after little time but then you will improve. There is nothing too op or too much nerfed, it is well done in this part.

[b] Challenge [/b]
This game is very challenging, both because of the leaderboards and because of the ever increasing difficulty and number of enemies. I'd rate the challenge of this game at High.

===

[h1] Technical Analysis [/h1]


[b] Graphics [/b]
Graphics style is quite simple and by no means high poly, but it compensates with some quite cool destruction effects, is quite polished and has good details on models of enemies and allied crafts. Too bad the background is quite low res, and also the wrecks of enemy fallen ships do fall on the ground but disappear after some time... would be more enjoyable with all those wrecks around to testify your defiance, but again i suppose it is for performance reasons.

[b] Sound [/b]
Sound effects are alright, average, some additional soundtracks would have been nice, overall decent.

[b] Performance [/b]
Smooth, well done, not many elements on screen anyway, should run well on even low spec systems.

[b] Stability [/b]
Nothing to report.

[b] AI [/b]
Enemy AI as you would expect is a basic point and shoot AI, nothing elaborate, but does the job.

[b] Quality of Life [/b]
Not Applicable.

[b] Bugs / Issues [/b]
Nothing to report.


[h1] Conclusions [/h1]

Furious angels is a game i suggest purchasing to anyone who likes competing in leaderboards and such things, but also to classic shooter enthusiasts. It is an above average game for its kind nowadays, you won't be disappointed.

[h1] FINAL RATING: 76 / 100 [/h1]
